summary.text:
**Considering citations in summaries**

I'm thinking about how to include citations effectively. It seems better to put them in the summary as inline parenthetical citations, like "(see proofs.md)." We can list the files we relied on as highlights too, such as "proofs.md" and "research notes." However, I need to remember the guidelines about having 3–7 bullet highlights. I want to keep the facts clear while minimizing verbosity. Let's start crafting the content!

**Summarizing research findings**

From the research notes, there are several key insights. We found an equivalence between R recurrence and scheduling, alongside concepts like subgraph monotonicity and lower bounds in degeneracy. I need to highlight fixed values for complete graphs and bipartite graphs, results on cycles like C3 and C4, and the implications for algorithmic filters, both fast NO and YES. It's important to ensure I choose 6 highlights to effectively capture these aspects without losing essential details.

**Organizing highlights and questions**

The developer requested 3–7 concise bullet highlights, focusing on key facts like reductions and counterexamples. For our next questions, I need to prioritize a few open inquiries. I think we should choose three: (1) Prove h(C_n) = 2 for a general schedule, (2) Settle the classification where h(G) = 1 if and only if it’s a forest, and (3) Decide if h(G) is less than or equal to treewidth or design a dynamic program. Citations to "proofs.md" and "research notes" should be included in the summary.

**Compiling citations and summary**

The developer wants to include "1–3 citations," so I’ll add a line at the end of the summary saying, "Citations: proofs.md; research notes," which should meet the requirement. I’ll create a concise one-line summary under 100 characters, like: "Recorded bounds, exact values, C5 schedule; open questions: cycles, k=1, treewidth/DP," which is about 89 characters. I must ensure the complete summary stays under 200 words and is readable, including mentions of equivalence, monotonicity, and various algorithmic consequences. I’ll finalize this in JSON format, with 6 highlight bullets.

{
  "summary_md": "Recorded and verified core definitions and elementary bounds for the hunters–rabbit evasion number h(G). Proved schedule verification equivalence (R_{i+1}=N(R_i)\\S_{i+1}), subgraph monotonicity, lower bounds h(G)≥δ(G) and ≥ degeneracy(G), and upper bound h(G)≤τ(G) (capture by shooting a minimum vertex cover twice). Determined exact values h(K_n)=n−1 and h(K_{p,q})=min{p,q}; cycles: C3,C4 have h=2 and we give an explicit 4‑round 2‑hunter schedule for C5 (odd cycles need time-varying schedules). Algorithmically: fast NO filters (degeneracy>k or ω(G)≥k+2) and fast YES via τ(G)≤k, but NP-membership remains unestablished because schedule length may be exponential. Open targets: general proof h(C_n)=2, classify h(G)=1, and whether h(G)≤tw(G) or an n^{O(k)} separator DP. Citations: proofs.md; research notes.",
  "one_line_summary": "Basic bounds and exact values recorded; C5 2-hunter schedule; open: cycles, k=1, treewidth/DP.",
  "highlights": [
    "Schedule verification: S_1..S_t wins iff R_t=∅ with R_{i+1}=N(R_i)\\S_{i+1}.",
    "Monotonicity: h(H)≤h(G); lower bounds h(G)≥δ(G) and h(G)≥degeneracy(G); K_{s,t} gives h≥min{s,t}.",
    "Upper bound: h(G)≤τ(G) (shoot min vertex cover twice); gives fast YES via FPT vertex cover.",
    "Exact values: h(K_n)=n−1; h(K_{p,q})=min{p,q}. Cycles: C_3,C_4 have h=2; explicit 4-round 2‑hunter schedule shows h(C_5)≤2.",
    "Algorithmic filters: fast NO if degeneracy>k or ω(G)≥k+2; NP-membership unsettled due to unbounded schedule length.",
    "Corrections: earlier mistakes fixed—h(K_n)=n−1 not n; 1 hunter can win on P_4 (conjectured h(P_n)=1), and fixed antipodal-pair schedules fail on odd cycles.",
    "Files: proofs.md; research notes."
  ],
  "next_questions": [
    "Prove h(C_n)=2 for all n≥3 and record constructive schedule.",
    "Resolve k=1: characterize graphs with h(G)=1 (is it exactly forests?).",
    "Investigate whether h(G)≤tw(G) or design a separator-based DP yielding n^{O(k)} recognition."
  ]
}

content.text: {"summary_md":"Recorded and verified core definitions and elementary bounds for the hunters–rabbit evasion number h(G). Proved schedule verification equivalence (S_1..S_t wins iff R_t=∅ with R_{i+1}=N(R_i)\\S_{i+1}), subgraph monotonicity, lower bounds h(G)≥δ(G) and hence ≥ degeneracy(G), and the upper bound h(G)≤τ(G) (capture by shooting a minimum vertex cover twice). Determined exact values h(K_n)=n−1 and h(K_{p,q})=min{p,q}; cycles: C_3,C_4 have h=2 and an explicit 4-round 2-hunter schedule shows h(C_5)≤2 (odd cycles require time-varying schedules). Algorithmically: fast NO filters (degeneracy>k or ω(G)≥k+2) and fast YES via τ(G)≤k, but NP-membership is unresolved because winning schedules may need unbounded length. Open targets: prove h(C_n)=2, classify h(G)=1, and investigate h(G)≤tw(G) or an n^{O(k)} separator DP. Citations: proofs.md; research notes.","one_line_summary":"Verified basic bounds and exact values; C5 2-hunter schedule; open: cycles, k=1, treewidth/DP.","highlights":["Schedule verification: S_1..S_t wins iff R_t=∅ with R_{i+1}=N(R_i)\\S_{i+1}.","Monotonicity and lower bounds: h(H)≤h(G); h(G)≥δ(G) and hence ≥ degeneracy(G); K_{s,t} gives h≥min{s,t}.","Upper bound: h(G)≤τ(G) (shoot a minimum vertex cover twice) — yields fast YES via FPT vertex-cover.","Exact values: h(K_n)=n−1 and h(K_{p,q})=min{p,q}. Cycles: C_3,C_4 have h=2; explicit 4-round 2-hunter schedule shows h(C_5)≤2.","Algorithmic filters: fast NO if degeneracy>k or ω(G)≥k+2. NP-membership of the decision problem is unsettled due to potentially exponential schedule length.","Corrections recorded: h(K_n) corrected to n−1; 1 hunter can win on P_4 (conjectured h(P_n)=1); fixed antipodal-pair schedules fail on odd cycles."],"next_questions":["Prove h(C_n)=2 for all n≥3 and give a constructive schedule.","Resolve k=1: characterize graphs with h(G)=1 (is it exactly forests?).","Investigate whether h(G)≤tw(G) or design a separator-based DP that yields n^{O(k)} recognition."]}

one_line_summary.description: Brief one-line summary for UI display
one_line_summary.title: One Line Summary
